column4: a Senior Human Resources Generalist/employee Relations Specialist 1
column6: I would make sure to have a discussion around the benefits of not sharing personal information with others outside of HR as there is no need for any of them to have that info.

I would tell the employee that you would not bring it up normally but since they had been conversing with others including customers you wanted to address it. That should help you avoid any claim of violating his medical privacy. I would then ask if his physician has given him any restrictions you would need to evaluate for accommodation. If his answer is no, reiterate to him that you expect his work to be at standard and that you would appreciate it if he doesn't share medical information with customers since it may make them uncomfortable.
If he says he needs to be accommodated ask him for a letter from his physician stipulating his restrictions. After receiving the information as a company determine what accommodations you can provide. Remember, the physician doesn't tell you how to accommodate, just what restrictions he has, for instance, if he is easily distractable and the doctor suggests a private office, the doctor is defining the accommodation which is not their role. There are many other options to deal with "distractions" things like desk placement, noise-canceling headphones, moving him from a highly trafficked area, etc.
Hope this helps.

I worked from home for quite a few years from the time I became a single parent when my children were 2 and 5, until they were teenagers and I trusted them to come home and be alone for a couple of hours until I got back from work. The early years were tough because I had such young kids. The 5 year old was in 1/2 day kindergarten Monday to Friday, and the 2 year old was in an all-day program one day a week, so they were around me for half the day at least. I managed it by working in chunks of time throughout the day. I would read to them or play with them for an hour and then work for an hour while they continued playing alone. I worked while they napped in the afternoon for a couple of hours. It's definitely not an easy thing to do. Many times they would sit under my desk and play with Lego or their dolls. Sometimes I would spend half an hour with them in the kitchen making a batch of play-doh, then leave them to play with it while I worked. The majority of my work in those early years was done at night, after they went to bed. Schooling at home might work the same way - you'd have to spend time going over the day's lesson and then do some of your work while they were doing the assignment for the day's material. Then onto the next subject, teach the lesson, then work while they do their assignment. If you can get into a regular routine, you can manage. It will mean working evenings, sometimes into the early morning hours, and probably need to do some work on Saturday and Sunday as well, but that's the trade-off if you want to have them at home. If you can afford to hire someone to come in for even half-days to monitor the kids while they're doing school work, that would give you four solid hours to work without interruption.

Therapists are usually professional psychologists. Psychologists are not licensed physicians - which means they can't prescribe medications, and are limited in what diagnoses they can make (and their diagnoses won't always be accepted by physicians, especially when it comes to prescribing medications).

To get a diagnosis that will be broadly accepted, you will need to get the testing done by a psychiatrist, which is a physician with specialized training in psychiatric conditions (including ADHD and autism).

A lot of health insurance plans require you to see your primary care doctor for a referral before seeing a specialist of any sort. It's a cost saving measure for them, if your primary care doctor doesn't think it's necessary they're supposed to say no (plus it adds a step and so some people just won't bother). If your plan doesn't require referrals normally you shouldn't need one to see a psychiatrist.

This might be long but stick with me. I am a nurse with autism. Sometimes I feel like the psychosocial has held me back at times but I really have made it work in my favor and I have developed tricks along the way. The most difficult thing for me is making eye contact with people and saying few words; I'm very to the point. My first interactions with people I make a conscious effort to look people in the eye and respond appropriately; which does take practice, try practicing with friends or family with social interactions. After a few interactions they usually talk to me while I'm working, so it is an excuse not to look them in the eye and usually no one brings it up.

As for what I do. I work in home healthcare, working with children/young adults with intellectual disabilities and usually autism; most are nonverbal. A lot of these individuals have underlying medical issues, most notably are g-tubes. I have a great ability to read body language and nonverbal cues which is great to have in my job. I am also great at routine, which these individuals tend to crave. I have been thinking about working in a group home but that's another conversation.

In short: practice social interactions with people you are comfortable with and you can even ask them what you may need to work on. Find your strengths, find your niche, find a job that suits you.
